posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26236974
I would imagine so, if you're switching from one to the other, but it's not like adding 200g to an otherwise comfortable helmet would make it feel awful.

Going from my road helmet to my dirt one is about 400g and that feels massive and I do prefer having something that light, but I don't mind the heavier one either. However if it was 400g the other way that could feel pretty bad at nearly 2kg, not for the weight increase per se but because that's a significant amount of weight for the neck to support.

tldr; aim for around 1500g, a lot heavier could be tiring, lighter probably isn't worth the extra cost

If your car smells musty it's because there's mildew living in it somewhere. You need to find the source of it and actually clean it out and not try some bandaid gizmo "fix". First change your cabin air filter and make sure the evaporator box isn't filled with leaves and mold and crap.
If it continues to smell, take the seats out, shampoo them and shampoo the entire carpet. If it persists after that take the carpet out as well and bleach all the metal underneath. Check all your seals carefully and see if water is getting in somewhere, if so fix that as well.

If you are not selling the vehicle 'as is', declare the technical specs of the vehicle and deliberately omit the tach there's is grounds for fraud because you are deliberately omitting a known issue with the vehicle.

In either case, you must declare the fault if inquired, failure to do so is fraud.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26235667
realistically if you treat your car like an appliance that is roughly how long it will go. however, there are a lot of other factors such as the age and engine type, what part of the country its from, etc. it goes without saying that cars from the salted north don't last as long as those in the south, and a car with 200,000 miles that's had good care and maybe a couple owners could be just as good as a 80,000 mile car that just came off rental duty.
with even basic maintenance the 3.6 pentastar in the newer chrysler vans will go for much longer than that, you're far more likely to have a transmission failure because of the age and the general attitude of the auto industry to simply let trannies kill themselves (lel) with "lifetime" fluid that lasts just long enough to get the car out of powertrain warranty.

there is no hard cutoff where a car that does a certain number of miles just begins falling apart, but there are important, load bearing parts that are often difficult or expensive to get to that will cause a cascade of separate issues if not dealt with BEFORE the car gets there.
even something as simple as a timing cover gasket leak can lead to a catastrophic failure (usually fire).

Looks decent, here is a list of things to confirm before buying the car

>A/C vent position working through all settings? (beware of blend door failure)
>headlamps don't randomly turn off by themselves (light module failure)
>engine is quiet and free of ticks / grinding / clanking noises?
>absolutely any suspicious noises on startup, especially the sound of a long metal chain slapping into the front cover of the engine?
>does the owner have maintenance receipts including oil changes?

That Town Car is a decent example, good color as well. Lack of A/C makes it more like a $2,500 car, not a $3,800 car, but in this inflated market, you may not have good luck. I would offer him $3,000. If he refuses, walk, and go buy a 2004 and up Grand Marquis

Definitely check it out. The bolt has a 65KWH battery and the EV gets 259 miles (EUV slightly worse at 247). If you're getting 21 mpg that means you would have to buy 12 and a third gallons of gas to go 259 miles. Now you have to look up your electrical prices for off peak times. My off peak rate is about 8 cents per KWH and they have a special plan for EV drivers that lowers it down to about 6 cents per KWH. At 8 cents/KWH that comes out to $5.20 to go 259 miles. With current gas prices near me at 3.20 a gallon that comes out to be $39.46 to drive the same amount in your car. That is over 7.5 times cheaper. You said you spend 6k in fuel each year so you would be saving over 5k per year in fuel costs if you have similar electricity rates.

posts.com:
In March 2000, auto sport Magazine of Japan’s front page carried the story that MTCI Racing Team would enter the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM for the upcoming JGTC season, the ultimate “GT1 prototype” racing against the Supras, Skylines, and NSXes. Little is known about the entry apart from Marco Apicella being appointed as the first driver.

However, somewhere along with the negotiations between MTCI and Mercedes-Benz, and perhaps in large part from the shame of the CLR’s massive failure at Le Mans in ‘99, the sale fell through. MTCI Racing Team would instead field a privately-built Porsche Boxster in GT300, with Apicella driving.

By season’s end, MTCI and its race team had collapsed into bankruptcy after the dot-com bubble burst. Chairman Yu Hayakawa was later arrested in 2002 for stock sales fraud. And save for its victory in the 1998 Suzuka 1000km, the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM never raced in Japan

>>26238326
Moslers actually raced in quite a few national-level GT championships like Grand-Am British, Belgian, Spanish, Australian GT series as well as Grand-Am, several SRO series, and a few rounds in FIA GT as an invite until the homologation rules made it so that a small-scale manufacturer could never be eligible for championship points. The car was fast, but also cheap to buy and cheap to run. It's downfall was not being eligible for homologation and just different series nerfing it because of its engine displacement.

The Japanese series would probably see the most of the different variants of the car through the years. It would have the original R, then the GT3 spec, and then the Judd-powered M.

>>26232529
Pickups benefited from one of the most successful lifestyle marketing campaigns ever devised by man, right below religious salvation, human rights, representative democracy, infinite compound growth, and unlimited borrowing into the future. It used to be that people bought them for the rugged appearance, bigger than you crash safety, and tough "get out of my way" looks, a popular persona adopted by frustrated commuters that are ten minutes late to work already.

These days people just want trucks, because they want trucks. The circular logic has now been firmly embedded into the public to the point where they don't really have a good reason beyond that. It's an extension of their identity, as evidenced by the immense aftermarkets available to personalize them.

Now, a few people do buy them for utility, but you won't find them in downtown Atlanta or the outer suburbs of LA. They're way out yonder in the middle of nowhere, where the only way to traverse the land reliably, no matter rain, sleet, snow, or apocalypse, is with a AWD or 4x4.

Personally, I like them, but wouldn't want to own one. They do make driving in 40+ mph crosswinds in the middle of a Midwest winter blizzard a lot easier though. Doing that in a compact car is an exercise in attrition, and General Winter always wins.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26234316
The non joke answer that doesn't involve games released 15 years ago is GRID: Legends for some sort of "motorsport progression" experience, Gran Turismo 7 is a bit of a disappointment if you're out for the Gran Turismo experience but it's not a bad game, Project Cars 2 if you want a slightly more simulator tier approach and a long career more spanning several types of car and track. Finally the Codies F1 games and Dirt Rally 2.0 are probably the best "single discipline" racing games but you may get bored of doing the same thing over and over. Whatever floats your boat there. Wreckfest is another really good option for racing something a bit more "random" like shitboxes and lawn mowers but genuinely fun.

For older games, Race07 is genuinely a great game to play but it is older and you'll need ALL DLC to have fun. The first GRID Game is also very good.

Finally for literally "racing" games WipEout is my personal favorite, alternatively RedOut 1 (not 2) and BallisticNG on PC are very good spiritual successors.

Assetto Corsa is only a good single player game if all you want to do is hotlap, drift and take screenshots. The AI is complete and utter garbage and even a reasonably slow driver will run circles around them. AMS2 is a scam at best. AMS1 is just reskinned rFactor (2005) and really only good for multiplayer (where it shines). Assetto Corsa Competizione has slightly better AI but the game is just so god damn boring to drive in my opinion and it takes a nuclear reactor of a PC to play. rFactor 2 is kinda ok for singleplayer but only on official tracks. Most usermade tracks confuse the AI and you'll run circles around them.

>>26231373
Yes, it is. It's not that different from a regular W211 except for the engine which is reliable, much more reliable that the M156 that succeeded it.
The trans is an old 5-speed auto that can withstand 1000+ NM.
The air suspension is finicky, but not too expensive to fix.
You do get electrical gremlins, the heated/ventilated seats on mine don't work and I'm in the process of getting some electrical wiring and stuff from other W211s to fix it.
Also it consumes a bit of oil, but I'm not too worried since it was a bargain basically.
I love it, the torque is brutal, the acceleration is great, it's going toe to toe with much newer and more powerful cars. Did a dragy run when I bought it and it got 10s for 100-200km/h.
Though you need grip, powerful 4x4 will beat you from a standstil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26233381
I can't speak for the M3. But truth be told, the E46 is much more confidence inspiring. It feels a heck of a lot more planted and refined compared to the BRZ. It also helps the the non-M e46's have comparatively longer wheel bases and are open diff, making them a hell of a lot less twitchy compared to the BRZ. Steering feed back is fantastic due to the nature of hydraulic assist. But that said, the BRZ just feels overall better and more fun, Especially after you do headers and a flash tune to eliminate the dreaded torque dip. That said, if you like small low power cars to throw around, its an absolute riot compared to the e46. Me being fidgety makes throwing the car into gears really fun because of the really short gear ratio. The e46 around town comparatively feels boring because of its longer gearing. Both clutches are lightweight, so traffic isnt an issue, but the e46 also feels a hell of a lot more numb and sluggish. Shift feel in the BRZ is way better, e46 is sloppy like all BMWs of that era Honestly, I've been trying to modify the e46 to feel more like the BRZ, and that says something. Seating position on both cars is great compared to other cars. but in the e46 it feels like you sit too damn high and the steering wheel angle makes it feel like you're driving a semi.The BRZ is perfect out of the box. The seats are comfortable, and the pedals, steering wheel and shifter are all perfectly positioned. I havent tracked the E46 yet, and by the time the car is ready, i feel like it will be too damn heavily modified to give an accurate representation of stock vs stock.. The BRZ has its flaws, but the overall is a way better platform. Its much lighter stock, 2800 vs 3300lbs. And the chassis is stiffer right out of the box. The E46 is the better all rounder and a better daily. The chassis has potential, but its overall structurally too weak for abuse. You'd spend a lot of money reinforcing it and taking weight out of a car is much harder than adding power.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226080
Electric AWD is easy to achieve, just put an electric motor/generator on the front axle, which is also optimal for use with KERS. For a PHEV like this, that motor generator should let them eliminate a lot of complexity from the gas range extender engine as well since it will no longer need a traditional alternator, and they'll almost certainly have electric climate control as well, like using a heatpump to move heat from the powertrain to the cabin.

AWD with a MR layout pure ICE car requires you to have a driveshaft going from the transmission at the rear forward to the front axle. Its a lot harder to engineer and you don't get any advantages from doing it that way.
You may not like it from a philosophical purity perspective, but PHEV really is the best solution today.

>damn near unobtainable
Might be putting it a little too strongly. I think anybody who is really enthusiastic about getting an ICE in the future will be able to. They just won't enjoy the current privileged place that fossil fuel dependent cars have in our current environment.

So if in 2050 you pull up to the fueling station in your restored classic air cooled VW Beetle, you're going to have to pay the true cost of the fuel you put in it, and those fuel stations may not be that common requiring a return to the days of needing a map to show you where the gas stations are. Kind of where EVs are today.

Lets face it, most people who are enthusiastic about cars are enthusiastic about the experience of driving them, not about maintaining 20th century relics. I'm sure there will be people who are, just like there are people who build and maintain Steam Engines today. Its just not going to be all that common.

Of course the flip side to that is because it will be such a small enthusiast minority there won't really be any enforced rules about it because rules tend to only get enforced if they apply to enough people for it to be an issue.

>implying electric vehicle charging is in anyway wide spread, convenient or fast.
Yes it is. At least if you own a Tesla like I do. Could the charging network in the Midwest be better? Sure. But at least it exists, and 250kW charging stations have really rolled out in the last few years.
The only reason to really use the nav anymore for trip planning, is that when it knows you're going to a fast charger it can precondition the battery so that it will charge as fast as possible and let you know when there's enough to continue the trip.

CCS cars probably do still need to do a bit more planning, but that's why a PHEV would be nice to have. Honda should just build a sporty car with a battery for daily range and peak performance and a little 660cc range extender motor.

By contrast Hydrogen fueling stations in the US only exist in California, and unless the only place out of California you want to go is Reno you're not going to have a very good time.

>>26237207
Not even all gas cars are good for long trips, especially not in places without infrastructure to support them.
EV infrastructure is getting pretty good in the US especially if you have a long range car with about 75kWh or more, and the ability to use both NACS and CCS.

Its not like gas stations instantly appeared everywhere the minute ICE cars were invented in the 1880s. It took decades for the status quo we enjoy now to emerge. Infrastructure for long recreational road trips in gas cars didn't really exist in North America till the 1950s 40 years after the first cars for the masses started appearing.
Affordable long range BEVs for the masses only really hit the market about 5 years ago, and they're already capable of long road trips if you want to use them that way.

If you can have one car, and you own a home. Buy a PHEV.
If you can have two cars, buy a short range BEV for daily use and whatever weekend vehicle you like.
If you don't own a home, buy a HEV.

If you're an enthusiast and you have the money, there's really no reason not to have a long range BEV as your daily car.

posts.name: Anonymous

I should note that pic related is after turkey bastering out what I could, filling it back with fresh fluid, "stirring it" and repeating 3 times in an attempt to get as much of the shit as I could

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26237449
Old brake fluid floats on top of new fluid. Remove as much as you can, fill with fresh fluid, let the gunk float to the top and then repeat until reservoir is clear, then flush the rest of your brake system normally

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26237477
that gunk is old brake fluid?

And corrosion. Brake fluid absorbs moisture, moisture corrodes brake system internals

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In a "bold" attempt at shitbox dress shoe design, the 1947 Davis Divan was an attempt at the three-wheeled car that ultimately ended in a similar vein as the Reliant Robin did in the UK, just a good thirty years prior to what is called the "Fiberglass Pig."

Its main selling point was its extremely good fuel economy for the day due to it being lightweight, and its ability to do tight donuts at a circumference of around 17 ft thanks to its single front wheel design. Its flaws, should be obvious even if they're to be considered "design choices."

Around fifty remain from the original production line as of today. The OP's picture is from 2021 in Amelia Island, Florida where three Divan curators took their pieces of garbage to an airstrip to drag race at a blistering 50mph for a hundred dollar grand prize. The airport was well aware of the stunt and endorsed it.

Because it's funny.

>>26228996
The head is probably cracked, the cylinder liner gaskets don't seal for shit, the valve stem bores are worn, it burns both coolant and oil, the dizzy was out of adjustment and it was running rich as I've overjetted the carb and never bothered to jet it down.
The CO2 limit is 1000, I think it was measured in mg/KM or some shit like that.
The exhaust manifold is a 2 tube one, divided in cylinders 1-3 and 2-4 if memory serves.
Cylinders 1-3 had a CO2 value of about 2800 or so, cylinders 2-4 had under 500, good thing it has a proper dual exhaust system so they just measured from the 2nd pipe and called it a day, otherwise they would've bounced it back immediately.

This engine is barely held together and now that it passed emissions it doesn't really have to, I'm gonna take it to get structurally inspected and drop in a "big block" 1.3 litre engine from a newer FWD Skoda and later on put an Aisin supercharger next to it.
I am not going to register the modifications as the car will be "grandfathered" on the 12th of this month as it will be 40 years or older, thus I get a 2 year long inspection slip, so that's 2 years worth of time with unregistered modifications

>>26233241
Every column shifter I've driven felt like stirring mashed potatoes and was ridiculously easy to overshoot. I've never driven one that was really usable with my hand still on the wheel either, at least it'd be so awkward that there'd be no point in trying to do it that way.
Dial shifters are far from my favorite but I've had them in rentals a few times and got used to them pretty quickly, and I found them as easy to use without looking as any other shifter. There are generally only four positions (PRND) and it's easy enough to remember that you just spin all the way to the right for D and two clicks to the left for R. I don't really see the need for a tactile indicator on an auto without low gears but if you do need to check there's always an indicator in the cluster.
Anyway the main thing I was talking about was people here always coming up with these ridiculous situations where somebody would accidentally put the car in reverse on the highway because they grabbed the shifter knob instead of the radio or climate one, but in reality the car won't let you do it and the knobs I've used are all different enough in feel and placement that you'd really have to be stoned out of your mind or something to even get to that point, and somebody that spaced out could just as easily do something stupid with a column shifter.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26236862
>Every column shifter I've driven felt like stirring mashed potatoes and was ridiculously easy to overshoot. I've never driven one that was really usable with my hand still on the wheel either, at least it'd be so awkward that there'd be no point in trying to do it that way.
GM truck shifters were pretty good in that regard, I was able to reach one on my GMT800 with my finger to shift while following the steering wheel rim with my palm or while slightly rotating the wheel. Did that from time to time out of laziness or while my other hand was occupied or injured, found the truck pretty suited overall for one hand operation.

>but if you do need to check there's always an indicator in the cluster.
The problem with cluster indicators is that they usually require your eyes to focus on them to read, while big sticks with R and D fixed positions far apart usually don't: you can feel that something's off using your peripheral vision or by placing your hand on them or where you think their handles should be (as with central console/tunnel shifters). I think it saves time and might greatly reduce the amount of low-speed accidents.

>somebody would accidentally put the car in reverse on the highway
Never saw this argument on /o/ probably because
>in reality the car won't let you do it

> because they grabbed the shifter knob instead of the radio or climate one
I would hate being able to do that, because if someone can legitimately confuse things so different, the designer responsible has failed spectacularly.

>and somebody that spaced out could just as easily do something stupid with a column shifter.
You don't need to be stoned, muscle memory can do many kinds of funny shit. Good engineer knows that, bad doesn't or doesn't care.

>>26236651

Middle class victims have been trained to think that a car is an asset instead of a liability

HOWEVER, you can get manufacturer financing for a car that's often way below what any bank can offer For example, if you finance a car that holds its value reasonably well at 0% APR and inflation is above 5%, you actually aren't doing too badly, because depreciation is offset by the effectively negative interest that inflation causes. And it's even better if you have the cash on hand to purchase, and then instead of burning the cash on a depreciating car, you invest that into something that produces a return and finance. You can end up with an effectively really cheap car

>$50,000 cash
>invest for a practically risk-free 5% annual return
>$63,000 at end of 5 years
>finance $50,000 car @ 0% for 5 years
>$50,000 in payments
>car's worth $25,000 at the end of 5 years
>-$25,000 depreciation + $13,000 profit = $12,000 loss over 5 years = $2400/year effective cost of purchase for a $50,000 car

and that's without getting into how inflation makes that car payment effectively smaller every year, and how 8% is a more reasonable target for an investment

The oldest zoomers are in their early 20s now. Hardly anyone has any real money, especially the ones who haven't graduated college yet.
I live in a lower cost of living area. My rent is ~650/month, utilities, food, and other payments bring the cost of living about ~850/month.
I'm working 30 hours a week while in college and I make like 28k after taxes. I can't reasonably afford a 20k car. I could make the payments on it, but it would be a retarded financial decision.
I'm lucky enough that from my current job, I was able to network and get a job offer making ~100k when I graduate in May. Then I'll be able to buy a decent car, but I'll have to be making student loan payments every month and would like to buy a house. That's 2k/month or more right there out of my ~6-7k/month I'll have after taxes. Avoid anything that's not a regular old manual.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been looking at part numbers, spec sheets and compatibility charts again.
Turns out the brake setup on the Espace 1/2 is very similar to the Clio Williams, which is identical to the one found on late 16V Twingos (same caliper mounting hole spacing, same brake disc diameter, they even take the same brake pads), but with one crucial difference: the Espace calipers get much bigger pistons (54mm vs 48mm).
They also cost less than 50 eurobucks a pop brand new. Might need a new master cylinder to compensate for the increased pedal travel but this is all very promising, it's not quite a big brake kit but it should all still just barely fit under 14" wheels and get you some extra stopping power.

Also if you upgrade to 15x6-7" wheels you can run Goodyear Eagle F1s in 195/45R15, which sounds hilarious for trackday sessions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226818
Oh and forgot to mention, if they work on the mk1 they should also work all the way up to the mk2 GT, the RS gets bigger discs and different 57mm calipers, from the Laguna I believe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26237617
Yes, a street car. I live in Middle TN and the car wouldn’t be driven during our brief winters. A mix of highway and local streets, more the latter than the former.

From what I’ve been able to determine so far, the Miata seems to be relatively inexpensive and easy to work on with good parts availability. But they’re also the oldest of the bunch, so higher mileage, more wear, more owners.

The Mini looks nice, is supercharged and is relatively recent, but they seem to be somewhat unreliable and difficult to work on.

The S2000 is somewhat aspirational. I love the looks and power, and I assume they handle well. But they’re also expensive, with prices in the mid $20’s and up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26237651
Miatas are very reliable and easy to work on, particularly the NA and NB. Perhaps NB or NC could fill the role unless you want the NA look. The S2000 is rewarding to wind out, but this is why I ask where you plan to drive, because if you don't have the room to wind it out and keep it there, it'll probably feel disappointing. For example, I got rid of my Miata because all the nearby roads are poorly maintained and straight. Didn't matter how fun the car's DNA was.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26236986
I would skip the BMW due to reliability and lack of soul. Skip the S2000 simply because prices are way too high for what you get.

I owned a Miata in the 90's, and I had friends who owned Integras and 240SX. If you really like the unique experience that is driving a Miata with the top down, and you plan to drive with the top down all the time (middle TN is a great place for that), then get the Miata. Otherwise, get the Integra-- more fun to drive.

For other cars you should be looking at, this anon >>26237617 has a good idea with the P10 G20. I also owned one of those-- lots of fun. Nissan sold a few other fun cars with the SR20DE in them, so keep an eye out also for the Sentra SE-R, 200SX SE-R, and NX2000.

>>26233736
My issue with subaru after 2019 is their use of the massive tablet infotainment especially as they hide many controls behind that computer. This is exactly the opposite of their previous gens which had screens but all of the controls were still physical and the screen only controlled media stuff. My second issue is with the CVT. While Subaru has made strides in improving their CVT reliability my big issues have always been the inconsistent power delivery in questionable conditions. The CVT computer or computer systems as a whole are known to refuse to transmit power purely to prevent a high load from being transferred through the CVT. It'll either use TCS to reduce throttle or the TCU will disengage the torque converter. The engine will rev incessantly but none of that power makes it to the wheels.

At 38k USD thats a lot of money for the cheapest XT. Thats basically top trim for most other economy car makers. I would still prefer other cars like the Rav4 hybrid because its AWD system is just as good for any realistic scenario and it gets a fuck ton better gas mileage.

one I've been pondering for a while is to add a cylinder pressure sensor and use the resulting crank angle vs pressure data to adjust ignition timing real-time while driving to adjust for AFR, base pressure, octane, etc in order to get the best (most power) timing on the threshold of knock at all times.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26237168
I don't see problems on XC40s nearly as much as other Volvos. The support battery is a lot more annoying to get to, but they don't seem to fail as often. The 4 cylinders have been known to burn oil across all models, but I have yet to see an XC40 come in with oil consumption issues. If possible, get a 2019-21 T4 or T5, avoid the P8 Recharge and the 22+ B4 and B5 models. Do your oil change on time, do the scheduled maintenance, and you'll be totally fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26237846
Both the T4 and T5 motors are only turbocharged, the T5 having a bigger turbo. Oil consumption issues is mostly confined to early 4 cylinders (2016-2018ish) due to worn piston rings, but I have seen newer cars with issues regardless of what kind of boost it has, albiet much less often. Maybe it has something to do with just hauling around more car? That being said, any T model XC40 should have the updated all gas 4 cylinder that seems to be much less likely to experience oil consumption issues. The B models have a different 2.0 4 cylinder and a 48V mild hybrid system.
Somewhat unrelated, but here's how to decipher Volvo trims after 2017:
T4: XC40 base, small turbo
T5: All models, bigger turbo
T6: All models except XC40, twincharged engine
T8: All models except XC40, T6 but hybrid
B4: 2022+ XC40 base, small turbo mild hybrid
B5: 2022+ All models, bigger turbo mild hyrbid
B6: 2022+ All models except XC40, bigger turbo and electronic supercharger mild hybrid
Didn't mention the new C40 because that's only electric

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: One last thing, do your services at the dealer. For some reason any non-Volvo technician shits their pants at the sight of a Volvo and doesn't know what the fuck they're doing. Aftermarket parts always suck on Volvos, you need to go OEM. Every time I see a car come in with aftermarket pads (especially on second gen XC90s and XC60s), they're always unevenly worn. OEM rear brake pads come with springs that help separate them from the rotors when you're not on the pedal. Aftermarket pads don't come with these springs, and as a result they wear like shit. XC40 doesn't use these springs because the rear brakes are a different design, but still. If you cheap out on maintenance, it WILL bite you in the ass. Volvo does not make cars for poorfags, take care of it *properly* and it will take care of you

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26231837
The main differences are the engine and transmission options. By and large its the same car throughout the years. Early years have a fully hydraulic controlled 4 speed automatic, later models got a "sealed for life" 5 speed but everyone services them anyway. That same 5 speed was used by mercedes deep into the 2010s because no transmission they had could handle the torque of the newer engines.
You could buy a few models of straight 6 over the years (even manual in the very early cars) and a v12 was added in 1992. Up until 1998, the v8 models had the 32v dohc 5.0 m119 (sauber c9, road car version) which was then replaced by the 24v sohc m113 - considered by many to be mercedes best engine. No matter what model you pick, they're all fantastic and reliable engines with a lot to enjoy. There's more minute differences between late and early but nothing too significant. Some models before 96 were affected by the infamous biodegradable harnesses but most have been replaced or junked by now.
Some people will argue in favor of the early cars, some later. The key is getting a car thats been maintained in good condition as they are all excellent.

>>26233276
People consider it a downgrade on stats but the street performance is the same. The m113 makes less hp but it's lighter, simpler, and more efficient (if it matters). The m113 has more low end torque, the m119 needs to be revved to really get the power.
In an m113 you don't have to deal with things like a water cooled intake manifold. The m113 does have 16 plugs, but they're easy to do and part of why m113s can run for so long. You also have a simpler valvetrain and timing system.
The purists will obviously prefer the 32v for the heritage but I'm just fine with the later engine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26237367

The best ways to find these cars is straight from big name Mercedes dealers. They aren't ever going to risk reputation damage selling 20 years problematic or lemons for tiny margins. Trade in usually go straight to auctions, the decision process on what old car get sold directly through them is a bit of a black box. Have a list of reputable Mercedes stores to monitor. If and when you find one, call them everyday until they can tell you when exactly it'll be out of service & detail. At that point you just have to be the first one to show up. It's how I bought my W210 E55 and R129 SL500. It can take forever sometimes but IMO this is THE best way to go if you aren't in a hurry. You pay a slightly premium but is off set by all the value added.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Long ago I spent a good chunk of my life working on vintage aircraft, and we used marvel quite extensively.

A buddy of mine was a director of maintenance up in Alaska on a couple DC-3s that got flown pretty hard.
At one point he had to swap out both engines on one of the '3s at the same time. It's pretty unusual to have two new engines on a plane like that. Usually you want to stagger them, for reliability and cost.
I suggested that he run an experiment with marvel. So he ran the left engine with marvel in the oil, and the right without. All 4 fuel tanks usually had some marvel in it. He ran this experiment for quite a while.

After the first year he started seeing the difference. Around the second year there was a night and day difference between the two engines.
The right engine had about the normal amount of sludge built up inside, but the left engine was insanely clean. It had higher compression, had a faster response to RPM changes because the prop governor and prop dome weren't sludged up, the engine oil temp was slightly lower because the oil cooler wasn't sludged up as well. Also, the left engine had lower oil consumption at only a 1/4 gal per hour, compared to the right at 3/4 gal per hour.

If you have a new engine, it's good to run marvel through the oil. But if it's a mid or high time engine, be prepared to change filters frequently for a while as the filters will fill up with all the crud that breaks loose.

Marvel in the fuel cleans the fuel system and helps preserve rubber seals.
We had to use them on the B-25 and DC-3 because of the rubber diaphragms in the pressure carbs.

Most importantly of all, it smells pretty good.

Yes, but I've long since stopped using my A&P professionally.
Always used 100LL. The DC-3 had 4 fuel tanks at 200 Gal a tank. I never actually "measured" the amount of marvel I used. We bought it in gallon containers and splashed some in the fuel while fueling.

Never noticed any knocking. But then again, we never used the engine's full potential. At take off power the engines are rated at 48in of manifold pressure (I think, could be 52in, can't remember), we were taking off at like 36in - 38in.
I had a DC-3 operator in Oklahoma call me once and he asked me if it was normal to change 3 or 4 cylinders a year.
When I asked him what his take off power was at he said that they used max power. I told him that would do it. Max power eats those cylinders up and there's no reason for it these days.

posts.com: Marvel mystery oil, mos2, ceratec, redline s1/techron chevron do work but you have to continue using them, it's not a one time thing. My j37a4 had really coked up piston rings and since I started treatment I could see on the boroscope they the cylinder head/walls/ring are much cleaner and free of significant carbon build up. I switched to an oil that doesn't flash as easily as well. Fuel economy shot back up and my tail pipes aren't nearly as sooty and power definitely came back over the course of the year and I got my third gear chirp back when vin dieseling.

posts.com:
A major war that affected the West seriously would be the end of EVs.

EVs are ultimately vehicles of prosperity and peacetime. They are less independent from the broader network of society than ICE vehicles. It is easier to scrounge for petrol and transport fuel over long distances than it is to maintain charging networks in a hostile environment. In theory you could charge EVs with portable solar arrays, but in practice this would be time consuming and expose you to vulnerabilities.

ICE engines are simply more durable and robust in uncertain sociopolitical situations, and if you believe the West is beginning to enter into those, it's foolish to buy an EV.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26236687
Opposite is true. The West has everything it needs to produce and run electric vehicles. Which is why every time there's been a war or an oil crisis electric vehicles have popped up since they're the cheapest and easiest type of vehicle to operate in resource constrained situations. Once they're built, they can run for years only needing electricity.

Another major war, like one that blocks the Straight of Hormuz, or destroys pipelines from Russia might very well be the end for ICE.

That's because you're driving a based Accord, doesn't need to rev a lot to do work, but they do sound very unhappy at high rpms, the whole cylinder head is setup to run below 2400 rpm with half the intake valves shut off while cruising in 5th gear.

>>26202738
I've owned 2 ashtray cars.
the car will always have a smell of stale tobacco, mainly during hot days but, you can get most of it out.
I copied the typical "disaster detail" steps you see in yt vids complete with seat removal, center console removal, deep vacuuming, soap, borax, and oxiclean solutions used with an extractor and drill brush on every soft surface.
the only spot I didn't hit super hard was the headliner because it was already weak in some areas.
even after all that it leeches out some stink in the summer heat. charcoal or baking soda cabin filter helps a lot if you run recirculation

it might be worth it if it isn't that bad and you can tolerate the smell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226861

Well, I'm at a point where I'm kind of regretting getting a car. Perhaps it's the moment to buy some tools and learn or die trying. I have to change on this car:

>VVT solenoid (or its gasket). Will the solenoid break when I take it out?
>VVT spool valve filter
>Oil pressure switch assembly

All these 3 leak oil according to the mechanic that checked the car. Also have to change:

>Shocks
>Rear brake pads

How feasible it is to do this if I haven't even done oil changes?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226906
I know it seems like the mechanic is trying to murder you with cost, but these are the things that do leak on Hondas, I even had VVT solenoid, the pressure switch, and the VTC strainer gasket leak myself. Since these cars are so reliable, I would check the oil every week or so depending on bad the car is leaking, and keep driving it to work, and fixing whatever you can afford to fix as you go about your business, whenever you get paid, buy some brake pads, whenever you get paid, buy a strut or two, and then keep saving and saving, until you can just show up at the shop and have everything done like I did, I would get a labor quote on everything, so that you know how much you need to save, a new Honda is breaking the bank, and then another used Honda is just gonna need the same things due to sheer age, so maybe fixing what you've got and continuing on as the rest of the car is healthy is a good idea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm an auto engineer, I worked on the development cycle of a truck where we designed/integrated rear steer, scrapped it, did it again with a different design, the scrapped it again before release. The main issue on anything RWD/AWD is it's very annoying to package. You have to make concessions with a bunch of other parts in the area, it adds a lot of mass, complexity, and long term maintenance, so it has to pay off. If you drive it and some people don't like it, or it's hard to notice the benefit, or some downstream result of the integration becomes a problem (maybe you had to make the damping harsher because you couldn't package enough swaybar for instance) it's not worth doing.

>>26236953
>You were literally paying $55k
£30k with inflation from 2011 is £36k today. That's 43k USD today. I don't know where you're getting $55k from. Nobody was paying $55k for an R34 GTR in 2011. The 80 original UK spec cars that were brought in where £54k when they were new in 1999/2000 (that's just shy of 100k for inflation) An E46 M3 was between £46-58k when new in 2001. The UK spec cars included a load of differences from a standard V-Spec (on which they were based). They also came with three tuning packages through the dealer (who used to race Nissans in BTCC) with the most expensive being 15k with period HKS and Nismo parts to take the car over 500 horse and maintain the factory warranty (Mitsubishi would later do this for the UK FQ spec Evos through Ralliart).

R34s never really went below £30k in the UK, because they were supposed to be the last iteration of the GTR until the R35 came along. The only cars that went under that were the cars that were rotted out, heavily modified, or had been crash repaired as already mentioned. My mate's first R34 GTR was an import in the early 00s. He'd wanted a UK Spec Middlehurst car, but those sold quick. The only reason he could afford to import one when they were new was he was a deep sea welder working on the North Sea oil rigs and they get paid stupid money. He's had several over the years including midnight purple cars and a V Spec II NUR.

>>26226713
I believe vans are much more practical for city use than trucks. You can haul around deliveries or your equipment while it's safely secured in an enclosed cabin and not an open tray like pickups. Larger vans tend to have better cargo room than most pickup trucks, especially those half-ton crew cabs with short useless beds. This is why it's highly preferable to own a van if your doing labor work.

Pickup trucks are practical in some degree as well. They tend to have a higher towing capacity, their beds can be modified to your liking such as replacing it with a dropside/flatbed (pic related) which frees up more space than an ordinary fleetside bed, and you can haul stuff that you wouldn't dare put in the inside of your cabin like dirt, sand or something that shouldn't be inhaled. The only other big advantage they have over vans is towing large gooseneck trailers, which is beneficial for most farmers or ranchers, keep in mind those trucks are usually duallies.

t. truck guy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26226713
Loading/unloading pickups is much easier but weather matters (a lot).

I transport outsize and heavy items which a van body would make much less convenient to load when it permitted that at all, and a box truck body is annoying to drive because shit visibility while acting like a drag chute thus killing fuel mileage. I can easily have engines and transmissions forklifted into my pickups after harvesting them at salvage. I can easily ride motorbikes up my ramp or have ample room to winch them on dollies. I can easily carry outsize steel and other building supplies. Only bridge height limits what I can fit in a pickup.

Vans offer weather and theft protection, neither are big deals to me and I also have a box trailer and a dual axle car trailer. If van or box truck worked better I'd add one to the fleet. They do not for my specific use case. Only specifics matter.

Things either should have include Tommy Gate style liftgates which are cheap used, simple and easy to install. Many pickup users like the advantage of specialty service bodies which permit external mounting of generators, compressors and engine-driven welders. Flammable gas cylinders should be mounted externally for safety. The result is why typical service trucks look as they do, but box trucks can serve with some work.

Northern Europe has little but rainy weather so vans or box trucks are mandatory, and theft is a constant concern in urban areas anywhere. In that case get a van or box body. Note box bodies hold more than vans and mount to pickup chassis (though some have partial cabs based on van parts.

Americans being rich can afford motorbikes and jet skis which trucks are much more convenient to carry. It's still legal to burn wood here and trucks are easier to load, unload and clean. Transporting mowers etc is convenient by pickup so I do.
